review_title: Great Starter Sales Job, Not Much Beyond That
pros:
If this is your first sales job and you are enthusiastic about working, you can't ask for much more than what's given. The base pay is good, the commission is uncapped and fairly decent, there's a 401k matching program, and you're given a very generous amount of PTO on day one. There is comprehensive training (all paid) and while there are some bumps at the beginning, management will do everything in your power to prepare you for heading into the field. If you have the right supervisor, you are given an extremely generous amount of assistance and proper encouragement.

If you last at this job for at least a year and have produced a lot, it is extremely likely you will be hired if you apply to a B2B role or possibly even Supervisor, depending on how well your name is known around the office. 

Even if neither of these end up happening, you have extremely effective resume material that will undoubtedly get you hired elsewhere. Direct Sales has extremely high turnover, and those that last more than a few months and produce are extremely qualified for other sales job.

Ultimately, if you are a genuinely consistent superstar in selling the product, you will not have problems. Management will give you plenty of freedom and you will have plenty of money heading your way.
cons:
Unfortunately, as the months pass, the cracks usually begin to show for most that work here. The top reps in the office ALWAYS partake in some form of fraud, and while the blatant cheaters do get fired quickly, you will be left cleaning up their mess if you are assigned their turf. 

Management says it will not assign turf unless it has been 3 months since the last rep was there, but this is a blatant lie. I have been assigned turf a week after the last rep left, and even if you are a phenomenal rep, there is little you can do to salvage the entire month. 

It is extremely draining to be working here during slow months. The lack of sales is one thing, but management will hold daily accountability calls where they guilt trip you for not having sold, not having sold more, and not having sold more service units per sale. I understand it is their job to encourage, but the method by which they go about it is extremely misguided. Something similar happens in regards to taking PTO, where your supervisor will always grill you and make you feel guilty for doing so. Very unprofessional.

I mentioned having a very supportive supervisor but from what I gather through the grapevine this is actually the exception and not the norm. Most supervisors in the office do little more than head out into the field to shadow you and remind you to follow up with customers. Mine took most of what wasn't selling out of my hands and into his, but when you do not have this privilege, it is a tough game of micromanagement.

Since you're working from 1:00PM-9:00PM as well as on weekends the work-life balance is just not there.
Advice to Management
Shift toward a culture of positive reinforcement and back away from always focusing on the negatives. Your employees are talented and will perform better if they feel their management is confident in their abilities. Stop babying the entire office if we aren't having a stellar month.

review_title: Awesome support and can be good income
pros: Good leadership, excellent benefits. Health, vision dental, savings and retirement accounts. You pretty much manage your time. Spectrum Expects you to be on the doors for a certain time each day, but you have the freedom to go use the bathroom take a quick break or work anytime. Hey make sure you know what you are doing before you go out on the doors as well. Really good on boarding process in terms of introducing you to the company. They offer sales incentives almost every week and the incentives are good for people at any skill level to achieve. Overall, the freedom you have working here is very nice especially in the direct sales rep rep position. You really get to be your own boss, with an excellent support team behind you.
cons:
A lot of their ads they advertise starting salary range of about 65,000 a year and they do emphasize that it is a potential that a sales rep can do, but I doubt that most reps get quite that much. I’d say I am an above average sales person, but I Only earned about 50,000 this past year. They do give you leads, but the leads are just addresses that they know don’t have our services currently. They revisit these leads every three months, so you may end up liking the same house multiple times in a year. In many cases The leads already know what you’re doing. This isn’t a bad thing or you can just get a repetitive. Because they are visited so often, it can be hard to make sells some months.They offer sales incentives almost every week and the incentives are good for people at any skill level to achieve. They are working on making the leads even better though which is nice! Like most door-to-door sales jobs, the best hours to work are when people are home. This means do you want to make sure you are working between five and 8 to 830. During the summer it’s not too bad, but during the winter it gets dark around 5 o’clock and it can be a little sketchy knocking on someone’s door in the middle of the country at 8o’clock at night. I had a gun drawn on me a few times, luckily people here in North Carolina our just worried about safety so they never shoot. I really like my family time, and so I miss being home in the early evening And I feel like I miss out on events because of this, but I do get to stay at home for the morning time.
Advice to Management
It’s been a while since I started working at spectrum, so I’m not sure if how the on boarding process is. But it would be cool to have a better us start up in regards to training sales reps.I really like my family time, and so I miss being home in the eveningAnd I feel like I miss out on events because of this, but I do get to stay at home for the morning time.
Helpful (1)

pros:
Benefits are amazing! Healthcare, vision, dental, 401K match, tuition reimbursement, legal help, childcare, etc. 
Opportunity of growth but you have to wait at least 1 year to apply for a different position.
cons:
Covid is not helping. Training was hard because you cannot interact a lot in order to learn. Once you finish your training and go to “nesting” taking calls, there’s only 2 people helping a group of 15 Reps answering questions. Since they cannot be close to you everything is through Skype which makes things more complicated. You have to wait until they are available to help you. You end up by being on a 45 minute call with an upset customer on the line because you are taking so long.
Advice to Management
There must be a way to listen to calls and watch the system being used in real time for 2-3 days before starting nesting, that will avoid many mistakes and frustration for not getting help when needed.

review_title: Old school corporate environment and terrible salary and benefits doesn't help with their talent retention efforts
pros: Lots of opportunities to grow your skillset and easy to take advantage of corporate budget to pick up valuable skills that could be useful elsewhere (i.e. Tableau licenses and other software licenses, etc.)
cons:
Low salaries and benefits makes it difficult to retain talent and company is left with lots of incompetent people. Lots of bureaucratic deadweight. No bonus incentive for entry level employees. Heavy dependence on consulting companies and contractors means that there's an even worse rate of turnover that's already being influenced by their inability to retain talent and that leaves behind business intelligence vacuum. Conservative and old school work environment that can sometimes not be very friendly for people that don't fit the mold.
Advice to Management
Offer better salaries and benefits, a complete restructuring of the organization could also be helpful. Lots of people doing stuff that they're not qualified to do and lots of teams picking up the slack from incompetent teams that don't have the talent to carry out the tasks that they are responsible for.

pros:
* Work Life balance 
* Good health benefits 
* Work remotely 
* Perks (If you can sell) 
* Mileage expensed
cons:
Company has a terrible reputation for treating their customers like dirt. They don't care to churn and burn customers, unlike their competitor, whom will do whatever it takes to keep their customers happy and have consistent billing. Spectrum is a HARD sell... AT&T has crappy service! But you will hear ALL DAY LONG, how happy their customers are and how they are treated (Great customer experience). It's becoming very difficult staying at Spectrum hearing from people all day long about how terrible the company treats their customers or how inconsistent the network is (facts. My internet is intermittent all the time, and I work for them). You will hear AT&T customers all day tell you how they pay as much as DOUBLE the price and are happy with AT&T and in many cases, even have half the internet speed. That should give you an idea how bad Spectrums reputation is.

* Very difficult to meet quotas. The few that do, trust you me, they LIE LIE LIE and yes everything.
 
* The salary is a complete joke. Enough to pay for gas and lunch...
Advice to Management
Treat the people who employ us with a little more respect and come up with a better system to give customers an opportunity to stay with Spectrum with upfront and consistent pricing. It's 2021! Who's trying to pay $200+ a month for TV and Internet?

cons:

The stress is there. They try to hide it but the call volume will get to you. I suffer from PTSD from prior call center work. Its not much different from my previous work.

review_title: This was the worst customer service job I had ever had
pros: The pay was somewhat decent
cons:
The expectations were outrageous. Customers that typically call in were usually elderly or people who in general were technology illiterate. Because of this customers would get outrageously angered at the person on the other end of the line, which is usually pretty typical for call center jobs. The problem was you had no time to breathe between phone calls. Calls were always in queue and you were expected to take calls back to back. You were also expected to have a call time that was under 11 minutes while also performing a required intro and outro. I think the last thing that made this one of the worst jobs I had ever had was I wasn't even allowed to go to the bathroom when needed. I worked 4 10 hr shifts a week and during those shifts if I would use more than 5 minutes of personal time a week, which is the aux you needed to be in to go to the bathroom, I would be written up.
Advice to Management
understand that your employees are not robots. They are people, and sometimes words hurt. If a customer is screaming at you and hits a low blow some people need a moment to recover. Treat your employees like people. If you think this is not how you operate then maybe you should sit on the phones for 10 hours a day
Helpful (1

Thank you for your review. We appreciate your concerns as we work together through these unprecedented times. As one of FEMA’s Community Lifeline sectors, our services are essential to hospitals, emergency first responders, government facilities, the news media and our communities to stay connected, help flatten the curve and protect the country. Making sure we deliver these vital communications while supporting our employees is our top priority. 

To that end, we recently made a number of changes to our operations that will help our employees better manage through this challenging time. These include an additional 15 days of paid time off to be used for any COVID-19 related personal need, increased social distancing plans in all of our call centers and operations facilities, and the option for remote work for employees whose jobs allow them to work outside the office without endangering our obligation to provide critical services. 

We thank you for all you are doing every day to support our customers and communities to ensure they remain both connected and safe

We appreciate you taking time to provide us with feedback about your experience at Spectrum. We care about what past and present team members have to say. As a company, we strive to align our vision with our employees' experiences. When those things are not aligned, it's important for us to understand why so we can work toward a positive resolution

pros: The company has good training, most of the employees and leadership are great. Clear pay progression, annual raises, employee service perks, and many other benefits. Overall it's a great company that has a few kinks that should be expected with such a large company.
cons:
MICRO MANAGING 
The higher up you get the more corporate interference you deal with. Managers do well at trying to mitigate the chaos but logistics to the application is a nightmare. Quality is sacrificed for speed and the company has cut a lot of incentives to stay with the company. Many higher-end employees have switched careers or have taken demotions to get back into the field and away from management. Some very ignorant policies like not working on tech classes well working even if you have no jobs or are on light duty. By policy they rather you sit and listen to customer care. Progression raises we cut.
Advice to Management
Again overall the company is great. My advice would be to let your managers manage their teams. You cant expect fish to climb trees. Some of the best techs I worked with were very thurrell, precise, and professional but a bit slower because they didn't rush their metrics and that penalized them. Again let your management manage, the environment and relationship in the teams were honestly impressive but I get why so many managers wanted to step down, and why many people leave. Although there's a lot of freedom in the company it feels like there are very little confidence and trust in the people hired as managers so they ride their teams to push metrics which degrades the quality of service. I 100% love the family environment and completely agree with the competitive atmosphere. An incentive could even be added to the best teams to encourage consistent quality work. Again the largest flaw I see with spectrum is the micromanaging and unrealistic standards that hold repercussions for their team leads.

review_title: Stress and lack of appreciation took over all of the perks
pros: Career advancement, growth, change, benefits
cons:
Micro management, 60+ hours a week, unrealistic expectations, back to back calls, poor inter department communication/relationships
Advice to Management
The main reason for leaving was due to upper management team and HR. How can anyone be efficient being over 9-10!stores, 70 employees, and 8 lower management reports and be on back to back calls every day?? In addition to calls there was far too many responsibilities and unrealistic expectations left on an Area Manager. There were new stores opening every month and all of the setting up and hiring was left on the Area Manager and Lower leadership. 

When Mobile was launched a ton of extra duties were added with overall less pay due to negative commission changes. Mobile was launched prematurely with half way planning and systems. Retail can’t transfer calls or hang up like other departments do, they have to solve the issue as they are with the customer. But imagine not having an answer at all or a resolution due to lack of structure with a company. So we were up against constant battles and challenges with every department interaction. It was never one team one dream with the company. With every kind employee was 10 jerk ones that treated us poorly. 

There was also a huge lack of sensitivity around covid in retail and a continued focus on goals goals goals. This was also the case prior to covid and during big initiatives like all digital changes for the company requiring cable boxes ok every tv. That was horrible and done in NY during the winter! Imagine working out of tents in winter weather and having to serve thousands of irate customers. Who thought that one up? Again this was left on local leadership to set up tent vendors and hotels etc to hold the influx of customers in our make shift pop up stores. 

Upper management admitted to reviewing store surveillance to spy on staff to ensure proper distancing etc. It is extremely hard to distance while reps are setting up cell phones and interacting with 40+ customers a day. Lack of empathy and appreciation from both HR and upper management. Very large work load and no work life balance at all. On top of all that, customers treat employees like garbage and hate Spectrum. Lastly all other departments that the retail team had to rely on were rude and difficult to work with.
Helpful (1

Thank you for your review. We appreciate your concerns as we work together through these unprecedented times. As one of FEMA’s Community Lifeline sectors, our services are essential to hospitals, emergency first responders, government facilities, the news media and our communities to stay connected, help flatten the curve and protect the country. Making sure we deliver these vital communications while supporting our employees is our top priority. 

To that end, we recently made a number of changes to our operations that will help our employees better manage through this challenging time. These include an additional 15 days of paid time off to be used for any COVID-19 related personal need, increased social distancing plans in all of our call centers and operations facilities, and the option for remote work for employees whose jobs allow them to work outside the office without endangering our obligation to provide critical services. 

We thank you for all you are doing every day to support our customers and communities to ensure they remain both connected and safe

review_title: Make good money, be stressed out, you are expendable
pros: The pay structure is good
cons:
Develop a toxic relationship with communiation as you will get constant pressure and negative feedback from leadership. Company is structured like a pyramid scheme, the only difference is that you actually get paid, but it's onlt the bottom rung employees that generate revenue for the rest of the company. So they drive you hard and then fire you on a whim, We were instructed to mask the selling of home phone with internet sales. Then When spectrum fears an audit from the FCC they terminate the people doing what they were instructed to do. Some good managers/sups but they can only be kind to you to an extent, they have a job to do too. This is a toxic work environment. I went off of coffee working here because this job caused me so much anxiety, coffee would just push me over the edge. Go here to make money while you look for something else. You will start out working nights so you can do interviews at other companies the mornings.
Advice to Management
Look at the long game (I know this review will garner the same pat response from HR or whoever is responsible for replying to glassdoor reviews) Take an honest temperature of the culture that exists there. Most people if they could get a different job would/do. What does the turnover rate say about the call center?
Helpful

review_title: Turnover Role Beware for anyone with any sales experience.
pros: Good Health Benefits for a fair price, Free Cable
cons:
Extremely high turnover role, most reps last 8 months or less. Not really an IT sales job more of a telephone sales job, good for entry level telephone sales reps with no IT sales experience. Advertised as an IT sales job but it isn't. 1 time sale, and you have to make about 60 calls a day and send out about 120 emails a day and even then a very, very low % of reps make it to 60% of a quota in a month, managers constantly recruiting. Just look how often the job is posted and how many jobs are posted across the country for this role. It is a very high high turnover job but if you need a job for 6 months take it but it is rough, base salaries are a joke. If you last a year, which is rare, it is about a 75k a year job +/- but very toxic place to work. No reason to get to know your teammates names, they are gonna be gone in a month.
Advice to Management
Territories are way, way to small, tell Recruiting to stop telling people they are selling large enterprise clients that are 29-399 employees only to hire people to call on 8 person used car lots, small accounting firm, hair salons, etc 90% of the territory is not a fiber candidate. You have way, way too many reps calling on tiny things for them to hit their numbers. Your turnover is amongst the worst in the Telecom space and stop positioning this job as an IT sales job, it is far from it.
Helpful

pros:
Steady work.
Plenty of overtime.
Bonuses.
PTO (!!!)
cons:
Much of the overtime hours never make it onto the hours listed or paid. Supervisors get worried about their "quota," and if someone's extra hours reduced their "productivity" then they change your hours worked or make you clock off while on the job.
Every job a tech does is supposed to be done in about 90 minutes. It's not possible to set a time frame for unknown factors. You don't know the job until you get there. Ok, the customer is having internet issues, but what fires that entail? Am I swapping out a router and then go? Or am I replacing the line at the utility pole, then running it underground through a 300 ft conduit, then pulling it under the structure in a 1.5 ft crawlspace, drilling through the floor to get the line in doors and then installing new eqipment? Then I have to wait for another department to complete the coding so that the equipment will receive signal...
You see what I'm saying? Quota is for factory workers who attach part A to part B every day. It's not for a series of unknown factors in a technical job.
Veterans run the show. If you aren't an adherent of government worship then you cant join their clique (but do you really want to?).
Lastly, work dominates life.
The corporate and HR are completely disconnected from reality.
Advice to Management
Read the cons.
Helpful

review_title: Need for Corporate leaders to step up and step in
pros: Benefits, income potential and room for growth
cons:

Corporate leaders be more involved in understanding all areas of business and especially HR functionality, laws and regulations to make better business decisions and understand short comings and economic impacts in efforts to create best practices and seemless processes across all business units. review_title: Gained a Lot of Skills to Move ahead
pros: Learned to work with Routers, Switchers, Dalet Automation, Manage Commercials and much more. Eventually found myself in related fields such as livestreaming and learning to how to build broadcast servers on my own during pandemic. Learned to work as part of a team and understanding all levels of the team. Eventually decided to go back for masters degree so I can learn more about streaming and broadcast management. Supervisors are nice, got along with MCO supervisor well and always made sure the team was happy. This was my second gig at Charter also being an intern at spectrum news ny1 I decided to go upstate to learn new skills.
cons:
Not a 9-5 job. Shifts will be assigned to anything in a 24/7 cycle. Things will change. Rotating shift schedule should be an option for some. Dealing with some personalities is always tricky anywhere but everyone seems to be cool. met some people from Nyc area as well. Made some key contacts at both Albany and NYC and have professional contacts for future jobs. The best thing to have if you work overnight is to have friends on the other side of the world, so at least you can talk to people on your midnight break. Also, technology always changes so the knowledge that I learned here would change in 10 Years.
Advice to Management
You trained me well and helped me learn skills that would help me find work during a pandemic. I am grateful to all levels of the team including other master control ops and supervisors as work in this field is hard to find with this economy in such bad shape. Good luck to all of you.
Helpful

review_title: Toxic Company, impossible sell, poor leadership
pros: Salary was decent. This is literally THE ONLY pro.... but it has to be because it’s unlikely you’ll see commission
cons:
Toxic work culture. The director’s leadership style is patriarchal threatening and menacing. It’s an all around boys club in the worse sense.

Spectrum services aren’t unique or competitively price in anyway. Fiber internet companies are a dime a dozen. Spectrum doesn’t have access to many places in NYC and they don’t negotiate with pricing. The lowest ‘promo’ price is still double their competitors... ALSO requiring a THREE year contract. The rules of engagement in NYC allow the same Executives on top to perform... stealing opportunities from one another makes for a horrible work environment.

ZERO DIVERSITY!
Advice to Management
Diversify the leadership.... evolve management techniques... improve the product... find a way to have a holiday party... employees deserve that.

review_title: The pay is great to say the least
pros: Good benefits and the ability to make upwards of $10,000 in commissions if you really work at it.
cons:
They don't care about employees at all, all they care about is making their numbers so the higher ups can get paid. I had a family member pass away and while the employee handbook says that you get 3 days paid bereavement and HR assured me this was correct, when I come back to work they told that it was not, that it was only 1 paid day off WITH PROOF, and then they put me on a final warning about attendance over it, when I was a top performer in sales/numbers/commissions and rarely ever missed work despite the mental strain this job puts on you.
Advice to Management
At least pretend to empathize with your employees and care about their well-being, also make sure that everyone is on the same page about policy.

Advice to Management

review_title: Needs to focus on customer and employee experience
pros:
Competitive pay
Good dental and vision benefits
cons:
Makes front line job more difficult than it needs to be on employee’s.

Makes the process more complex and overly difficult for customers needing technical assistance.

Promotes within to rapidly, focused on quantity rather than quality.

Paid parental leave feels like a joke.
Advice to Management
Allow your front line tech support more access to basic functions with out needing to reach out to a lead or another department. This will reduce overall call time for the customer creating a better experience and empower front line creating a better employee experience. 

Rethink the paid parental leave, 2 weeks feels like a joke for a new parent.

Consider who you promote and how quickly. Seeing employees get promoted from within is great, but not when it compromises quality by promoting someone multiple times rapidly.

Remind your employees, specially those in leadership. To think as though the customer is in the room, instead of talking negatively about other departments or even certain customers.

review_title: Dont work here and heres why
pros: Free services, great benefits great coworkers
cons:
Management isn't the best. They want your opinion but at the same time they don't even listen to it after said and done. The trainings are almost never on what you actually do because they have several different teams there and you could be in a training for something totally different then what you will be doing. If you want better hours than what you are given.... forget about it i had to go a medical route due to my condition and that was even hard to do. Hr is honestly the worst they are supposed to help you but just give you sarcastic answers when asked or dont even answer your questions. To top of the schedule part of this you can get a shift from 2-11pm and be asking for a earlier schedule since itd be better for you and your family or etc as well have a pretty good and decent time into the company for example i was there for 3 years and they fought it but when new hires would hit the floor they would give them shifts like 8-5 or 9-6 and would still tell you they dont have the space for you to move to a earlier shift. As well dont try to argue that becuase they will hear you out but they dont really care and wont do anything to help you out anyways. The company is honestly a joke when it comes to management. Please look at a diffrent job if you want something where they will treat you better, If you want free services but like coming home being stressed out and wanting to just be a blob this is your place theres nothing truely here that is good in the long run. Last thing if you are a good worker, don't even think about getting a promotion. They will hold you in your position so they can use you like a work horse, but on the side they will go ahead and promote people who have absolutely no idea what they are doing while you are working your butt off trying to do better and help as much. they say they have career advancement opportunities but yet do stuff like that.

Paychecks arrive on time.

Free water at office locations.
cons:
Outdated corporate culture. One-size-fits-some remote work policy, with mandatory office attendance even for positions which do not benefit from on-site presence. Archaic dress code. Poor non-monetary compensation.

Siloisation inherent in corporations of a similar size which absorb other companies.

Installer, line, and data center technician positions all require direct physical presence- this does not hold true however for all jobs. Requiring employees to work from shared workspaces or cubicles in suburban office parks will ultimately cause the company to continue hæmorrhaging employee talent, and cause potential recruits to choose opportunities elsewhere.

pros:
*they provide detailed training
*support you step by step until you get the gist of your job.
*give you constant review and feedback
*everyone is very friendly.
cons:
*you’ll get yelled at by angry customers
*you cannot hang up on or transfer angry customer.
*have little to no leeway on accidental behavior.
Advice to Management
Give the representatives the ability to hang up or transfer livid customers. If not to everybody, at least let people with anxiety or PTSD do that. Also, if your representative has a rough day and accidentally cussed when their on hold and the customer can’t hear them give them grace just tell them not to do it again. Don’t just fire them and if it’s a repeated Occitan day then you should fire them. It’s not fair if I good employee has a bit of a rough day and cusses once and gets fired with no further consideration.

pros: Discounted/Free Cable & Wifi... that's why it's two stars.
cons:
The job itself and leadership. They make decisions that effects the workflow but lack input from their employees. The job, despite COVID still made employees come into work and doing a 50% on 50% off after prolonging a decision when they have full capability to be a remote department. People in various departments had/have COVID and still made employees come in. PPE took forever to be given out. Job is boring and routine, they will dress it to be something way different than what you will actually do. 
If you enjoy sitting at a desk all day in complete silence, doing the same functions every single day then this is the job for you. 
There very little room from growth unless your buddies with leadership.
Advice to Management
Become fully remote, listen to your people, actually see how your decisions effect your team and stop putting people in leadership roles that does not even know what a commodity code is.
Helpful (1)
Spectrum Response
September 29, 2020 – HR Specialist
Thank you for your review. We appreciate your concerns as we work together through these unprecedented times. As one of FEMA’s Community Lifeline sectors, our services are essential to hospitals, emergency first responders, government facilities, the news media and our communities to stay connected, help flatten the curve and protect the country. Making sure we deliver these vital communications while supporting our employees is our top priority. 

To that end, we recently made a number of changes to our operations that will help our employees better manage through this challenging time. These include an additional 15 days of paid time off to be used for any COVID-19 related personal need, increased social distancing plans in all of our call centers and operations facilities, and the option for remote work for employees whose jobs allow them to work outside the office without endangering our obligation to provide critical services. 

We thank you for all you are doing every day to support our customers and communities to ensure they remain both connected and safe
advice_to_mgmt: Become fully remote, listen to your people, actually see how your decisions effect your team and stop putting people in leadership roles that does not even know what a commodity code is.

cons:
ltant in Racine, WI
Doesn't Recommend
Negative Outlook
Disapproves of CEO
I worked at Spectrum part-time for less than a year
Pros
There were not any pros at this job.
Cons
The pay was not nearly enough for what all they requested the employees to do. You are left to deal with irate customers, even on your first day, training on the floor. They dont allow you the proper amount of training time. Everytime, aside from TWICE, while training, they made me stop training to help customers, instead of learning what I had needed to be successful within the store. While out sick with COVID, the harassed me every.single.day starting at 6am via text and phone, asking me the same thing wr had discussed the day before. I had gotten in trouble when i had came back to work for not answering all their calls, which is ridiculous. They couldn't care less if you have Doctors notes. I was told it doesn't excuse absences(even if whatever happemed was so severe it left you in the hospital), it only gives an idea of when you will be back. Sales reps TAKE your sales and will mask it by stating they're helping you. When the protests went on in the next city over, the racism of some of the reps jumped out. I was told by another rep that we(African Americans) need to get over racism and that the confederate flag isnt offensive because it was the past. I over heard this same individual making jokes about police brutality, he was Jewish, which is crazy to me. I ultimately ended up quitting, the money and lack of hours just wasnt worth dealing with any of this, when i can work with a company that pays more, gives more hours, and respects me as a human being. As well as respects me enough not to harass me daily while battling a serious illness.
Advice to Management
Do better.
Helpful

review_title: Great Benefits, Great Teams, Micromanaged to the core
pros: Amazing benefits, amazing pay when it comes to commission, endless possibilities to make great money and to really help businesses. The teams we work in are really supportive and helpful and they generally have a positive attitude and are great coworkers.
cons:
Micromanaged to the core. It use to be a very free dept where they trusted you to get your work done and make money. However after new leadership came in we began to be micromanaged more and more every month. Executive leadership that has never sat in our seats are telling us how to do our jobs constantly but they do not know how much work has to be done off of the phone. Yes we are telesales and I understand we have metrics we must abide by, however with them consistently raising the metric goals and lowering our opportunities to sell with policies that get made up week after week, it gets stressful. We have to do a lot of off the phone work and business owners and decision makers do not always have the time to speak on the phone, most like to email correspond. However, they still expect high dials and high sales with high talk time by just burning through the dialer leads.
Advice to Management
Have executives and leaders who have not actually worked as a telesales representative with the metrics they have placed on us to sit in our role for even just 1 week and see the amount of work, effort, time and stress goes into the role and how the executives are constantly making our job more stressful and not worth the stress.

review_title: Not worth the income it provides.
pros:
- Great pay for a relatively easy to get into position
- Decent Supervisors
- Near endless ability to make more money thanks to their commission + base pay model
- Relatively easy to move up to a supervisor position
cons:
- The general public is terrible
- The sales managers are far too concerned about your numbers
- Extreme pressure to perform in a position that relies entirely on things outside of your control
- Customers were routed to sales when they did not need a sales agent, impacting your numbers, and getting you in trouble

Store leadership is overloaded with responsibilities with no guidance or support. All systems are so outdated and redundant. Different stores are given different equipment to assist with customer traffic and help overall numbers but ALL stores are held to the same standards. Upper leadership holds discipline over your head and uses corrective actions as a scare tactic. Human resources is never able to answer direct questions. Regional managers tell employees they are able to do something that is clearly outlined as a violation of company policy. Job descriptions are very unclear. During the interview, employees are promised money that has been taken away during the COVID pandemic. Spectrum did not care about any of their front line employees during the pandemic. Required everyone to continue working with no extra compensation.
Advice to Management
Back up your front line leaders, they are the ones who develop future leaders. Practice what you preach.
Helpfu
advice_to_mgmt:
Back up your front line leaders, they are the ones who develop future leaders. Practice what you preach.
Helpfu

pros: They have an excellent benefits package
cons:
You have to know the right people in order to succeed. If you look for answers on your own and find a method that the higher ups did not know about instead of supporting you they get discouraged and shut it down. Upper management thrives on feeling needed and does not value independence or outside the box thinking. If you want to succeed in this company you need to not think for yourself and you need to be compliant. Things change on the daily. Be a, "yes man" and you will do well.
Advice to Management
Encourage your employees to be free thinkers, innovators and allot everyone the same opportunities to succeed. Make sure that when you hire someone for a leadership role that they are the best example and that they are not promoting fraternization and inappropriate behaviors, ensure that your leadership teams go through an HR course to know what they can and cannot say to employees PRIOR to them taking their role. Be proactive vs reactive in your approach.

review_title: Not what is used to be
pros: As a company, they offer great employee benefits. Insurance, Highly discounted (ALMOST) Free Cable, phone, and internet services. An excellent retirement accumulation plan, plus a 401k and 100% match up to 6% of income.
cons:
The company has or at least my regional leadership team has lost its focus on its employees. There is ZERO concept of work life balance and in my role there is no such thing as time away. Sure you get vacation, but why use it, you will work anyway. Preferred communication is harshly worded emails and motivation via intimidation - and that just was senior leadership says to your face.
Advice to Management
Your supervisor, manager, and directors are not slaves. Work life balance is important. Also - Keep your AVP's and RVP's in check, you are losing excellent talent, not because people dislike the company, but because they cannot stand being micromanaged by former Cablevision failures. When you focus solely on metrics and not people moral goes away because people become just an expendable expense. When you focus on people, moral improves the metrics.

pros:
- There will always be work available (if you're willing to sacrifice yourself and that of your loved ones).
- The company provided a 120 hour flex time to be used for when you eventually catch COVID-19
cons:
- Doesn't care about your health and safety.
- Doesn't care about preventing the spread of COVID-19
- They will do anything that can save the company some money, even if it means the health of it's employees.

- The company provided a 120 hour flex time to be used for when you eventually catch COVID-19. However, people who are smart enough to want to prevent catching it and spreading it attempted to work from home, but the CEO believes that there is no such thing as working from home so that wasn't allowed. At first the leadership allowed people who didn't feel safe in the office environment to work from home. The issues began to arise when they would request employees full access of their medical records so they can see IF you would fall within the CDC guidelines of an at-risk person. If they couldn't corroborate this, you could either report back to the office or indicate you live with someone that may be at-risk. If you do live with someone that could be at-risk, then they would also have to get a doctor to certify why that person is at-risk. Never mind the invasion of privacy to attempt to stay safe during a pandemic, but it's hard to feel safe in an office environment that week after week reports more and more positive COVID-19 Cases. 

If you're asking yourself WHY would a company would make an employee have to jump through so many hoops to avoid catching and spreading deadly virus, it's simple, they don't care. They do care however that if you do not use the awarded Flex Time, they would have to pay out a rough amount of $240 million at the end of the year. In efforts to save money, they force you to either quit, or use that PTO/Flex time to avoid going to the office, when all if not 99% of the office work has been done at home for over 6 months.
Advice to Management
Management needs to be able to override the Company's Employee Model of enforcing people to endanger their life and that of others.

review_title: Seems great but a lot to take in.
pros: Pays pretty decent on weekends and plenty of overtime
cons:
Lots and Lots of information. They data dump you for 6 weeks and then throw you out on the floor.
Helpful
Spectrum Response
August 17, 2020 – HR Specialist
Thank you for your review! Your comments are valuable to us and we will share them with our leadership team

pros: Co-workers can be nice. They will bribe you to be at work with snacks and popcorn. Charter reward points can be nice. They have insurance, not the best, but it's there. SOME management is great. Set schedule.
cons:
I don't even know where to start. Don't ever miss work, EVER. They bribe you to stay at work by sending emails to everyone about "prize winners" for not missing work during the month, yes during covid as well. 
Speaking of COVID-19 I could go into a lot of detail, but here's the main points: Unless you are considered high-risk and have documentation from a doctor from THIS YEAR you will be working in the call center & sharing desks (no assigned desks just find a seat and sit), masks are not required, if you fill out the information they have you fill out before coming to your shift & per that app you cannot go in you still get penalized for missing work. IT'S A GLOBAL PANDEMIC PEOPLE. Lighten up. 
Management will constantly tell you how you can do better & not give any positive feedback, even if you are a top performer. If you do miss work your manager will text you begging you to come in - yes, still during covid. They constantly compare you to other locations when those locations aren't following the same scripts/protocols/dealing with the same customer base . 
Video support & retention in the same building - yet treated unequally. Retention is royalty to them. 
Don't you dare take your lunch late because you're stuck on a call, that's an infraction.
They will not work with your schedule if you need to change it for any reasons unless you qualify for a new schedule and hope there is one that matches with what you need. Otherwise they'll provide one for 30 days. woo ,yeah that doesn't help. 
Customers are jerks but what is worse is that every other department gets to lie to this customers to get them in the door and video support has to be the one to clean up the mess and be the bad guy. If you do something wrong in video support, you're immediately spoken to about it & watched like a hawk. I'm guessing that same thing doesn't happen in other departments because it'll be MONTHS of the same thing happening.
If you request a day off, you may not get it approved, even if you're not trying to take sick/vacation time. I requested to take a day off for surgery and got denied and when I spoke with HR they said "Well, you shouldn't have scheduled the surgery without seeing if you could get the day off first"... Really?
Advice to Management
Don't treat your employees like a number and for crying out loud give them all an opportunity to work from home, it's a global pandemic. Only letting certain people work from home says you don't care about the health of your employees. Also, don't reply back with your "Per our FEMA" or whatever you reply back to everyone elses who mentions covid. You suck.

August 17, 2020 – HR Specialist
Thank you for your review! We are so proud that our benefits and training programs left such a good impression

pros:
- Excellent entry level opportunity for the cable industry
- Many valuable skillsets taught & learned that carry over to similar job markets
- At-your-own-pace progression for promotions
- Drive company vehicle home
- Gas, vehicle maintenance, uniform & tools provided/paid for.
- Accredited progression courses; you can achieve an associates or bachelors just by completing job-relevant progression courses
- Potentially valuable networking opportunities; limited only by your interpersonal skills.
cons:
- Heavily micro-managed
- Technicians are the face for the "bad-guy"; half the time you will be given no reasonable explanation to provide customers for their issues, the other half, the explanations you are expected to provide make no sense.
- The longevity of your employment is highly contingent upon the moods of your supervisor/managers; Charter Employee Policies are so vague that they are up for interpretation. If you excel at brown-nosing or get a supervisor you "click" well with, you'll at least be safe until either you royally mess up or switch teams.
- Every supervisor and manager runs things differently; Spectrum lacks solid standards and operating procedures, leaving departments and teams from the highest to the lowest echelons the ability to interpret managerial intent in whatever way they understand or so please.
Advice to Management
- Enable cross-department communication.
- Clarify company policies IOT enable a clearer understanding on the part of employees as to their full responsibilities.
- Enact policies that protect basic employee interests IOT raise work place morale and cultivate an environment that simultaneously increases job efficiency and employee longevity.
- Communication is the key to success; Supervisors and Managers spend the majority of their time on redundant conference calls that accomplish little to nothing, rather than directing optimal energy and time to teaching and assisting subordinates--an example of too much communication in the wrong areas; employees at the basic levels have no idea what is happening, half the time, because they are not being provided sufficient information IOT ensure they can keep up with constantly changing standards and procedures--an example of too little communication at arguably the most vital point in the chain of command.

pros:
- Pay and rewards aren't too bad, goals are pretty attainable.
- Not as high pressured as other mobile stores.
cons:
- If you go in expecting it to be a full on sales job, you have another thing coming. You'll probably spend the majority of time returning and issuing equipment, as well as dealing with angry customers wanting to complain about their bill.
- If you come from a mobile selling background, the system for selling phones isn't the most intuitive. It's a slow process to sell a phone but the worst part is you can get an error message at the very end of the sale, telling you the order cannot be completed in the store, no other reason is given for why the sale has failed. New ID capture systems have been put in, presumably to solve this problem with added fraud protection, however this system is broken and almost never scans an ID correctly first time of asking.
-A poor manager can really ruin the experience. The company is hellbent on beating other mobile providers, and is trying to make it a mobile store, despite it still being an Cable and Internet provider first and full-most. My store got a new manager in at the turn of the year and his mobile background has been an hindrance rather than a help. The clientele and environment isn't the same, Verizon it ain't. A total disregard of team morale, creating a toxic competitive atmosphere that has taken any sort of fun I had before in the job.
Advice to Management
If you want to become one the mobile big boys then make it easier in the system to sell mobile phones. As for the vast majority of customers we still get day in and day out, make it clearer to customers of their options for returning equipment, don't just have customer service tell them to come to the store when UPS is supposed to be our preferred option for return. Don't punish us for having us return equipment and count against us when you look at our unique transactions. As for loyal customers who had service for years before you took over the company that came before, give us more options for helping those out who have been customers for 20 years. Instead of just giving out the deals for new customers.
Helpful

pros: I went from minimum wage to this and wow is all I can say. The job is very free. You have to be in the field from 2:30-8 but if you choose to work earlier or later its no penalty. They pay you your full commission after 8 sales which is not a hard target to hit. I've seen reps making $85 an hour but a more average rep would be making around $17-$20 an hour. You get two "salary checks" every month which are around $600. Then you get a $400 gas check once a month and commission once a month. You can easily make $4000 monthly here and it is NO PUNISHMENT for being a good salesperson. The education assistance is real and easy to apply for, PTO time is very generous. I love this job and I honestly don't ever want to leave. I'm hoping to get my business management degree and eventually becoming a manager.
cons:
You have to use your own car, but you can supplement that by buying a work car with the money you make

pros: Free internet, take home vehicle.
cons:
This company is more concerned with micromanaging and how long you take on a job than they are with getting the job done right. You are constantly given jobs for the incorrect points when the company makes everything you do all about the points, so you are constantly having to explain wy your points are low when you do a job worth 30 points, for just 13 points. The company took away the dispatcher's ability to fix those points, thus leaving you to do the work even though you are not being pointed for it. Add in the fact that your bonus pay is based on these points, the company is literally ripping you off. You are expected to put your very life at risk and enter every single home, even if the fix for the job does not require it (with the pandemic, that is just outright dangerous and puts our lives at unnecessary risk, our very lives are being gambled with by this company) and when you bring up an issue with this to the company, you are told that maybe this job is not for you...imagine that, a 13 year vet of the business and I am told this job is not for me. This is not the fault of the supervisors, but the people at the top very of the company. Add on top of this, we no longer have specific areas, so our drive times have quadrupled which adds even more to our lack of points. We have been given more and more job duties on job but are not given more time to do them. We have one hour to complete a job, when the job may require several hours to correctly fix...add on top of this that when the job is not correctly fixed, we are hammered on for a customer calling back in. This company is vile toward its employees and I would never suggest anyone ever work for this company. There is so much more going on than this, but this should be enough to detour even the most eager of applicants. And no, I am not a disgruntled employee, in fact I put my very job at risk by writing this as the company literally monitors your online (private) activities even outside of the company. This is an authoritarian company and if you are thinking about applying for this company, do yourself and your sanity a favor...don't.
Advice to Management
Quit your jobs. This company is not worth it.

cons:
The problem with the organization is the focus on performance metrics opposed to behavioral growth, inconsistent (and oftentimes conflicting) direction with policies and procedures, as well as a tendency to promote until a level of incompetence. There is no culture and when an organization focuses on promoting only those who are successful in their current role opposed to potential, you run into a lack of effective leadership.
Advice to Management
Stick to a company brand, uphold the mission and values, put people before their ever changing metrics, invest in your staff, and exchange ineffective managers for real leadership.
Helpful (1)
Spectrum Response

August 26, 2020 – HR Specialist
Thank you for your review. We appreciate your concerns as we work together through these unprecedented times. As one of FEMA’s Community Lifeline sectors, our services are essential to hospitals, emergency first responders, government facilities, the news media and our communities to stay connected, help flatten the curve and protect the country. Making sure we deliver these vital communications while supporting our employees is our top priority. 

To that end, we recently made a number of changes to our operations that will help our employees better manage through this challenging time. These include an additional 15 days of paid time off to be used for any COVID-19 related personal need, increased social distancing plans in all of our call centers and operations facilities, and the option for remote work for employees whose jobs allow them to work outside the office without endangering our obligation to provide critical services. 

We thank you for all you are doing every day to support our customers and communities to ensure they remain both connected and safe
advice_to_mgmt: Take care of your employees. Treat them as people and not objects to warm office chairs.

cons:
First, The COVID response was terrible. The fact that WFM was not a thing is mind boggling, considering other telecoms have done it easily. 2nd, with all the calls due to the pandemic, and the push to get numbers up, it’s hard to feel like the company truly values the employees, yes the pay is nice. But it doesn’t feel like we are truly valued.
Advice to Management
Value the employees more, and do by more than just saying it. Pay is nice, but there’s more ways to show your employees they aren’t just a number.

Spectrum Response
July 28, 2020 – HR Specialist
Thank you for your review. We appreciate your concerns as we work together through these unprecedented times. As one of FEMA’s Community Lifeline sectors, our services are essential to hospitals, emergency first responders, government facilities, the news media and our communities to stay connected, help flatten the curve and protect the country. Making sure we deliver these vital communications while supporting our employees is our top priority. 

To that end, we recently made a number of changes to our operations that will help our employees better manage through this challenging time. These include an additional 15 days of paid time off to be used for any COVID-19 related personal need, increased social distancing plans in all of our call centers and operations facilities, and the option for remote work for employees whose jobs allow them to work outside the office without endangering our obligation to provide critical services. 

We thank you for all you are doing every day to support our customers and communities to ensure they remain both connected and safe
advice_to_mgmt: Value the employees more, and do by more than just saying it. Pay is nice, but there’s more ways to show your employees they aren’t just a number.

pros: The benefits are really great
cons:
They will hire you as a chat sales agent but you will actually be thrown on the phones as needed since they are so understaffed in the voice department. You get no training on how to handle phone calls, but your managers will constantly be ridding you about your metrics not being good enough since you have different metrics to meet when you take phone calls. The on the job training just teaches you how to use all of the online applications and programs you need to do the job. It doesn’t actually teach you how to do the job. So your already at a disadvantage of not knowing how to do your job as a chat representative, and then you have to figure out how to take phone calls too.

pros: If you know how to sale it’s not hard to make money, especially on months when there’s incentives on top...but you can literally sell anywhere.
cons:
First of all, store management knows next to nothing. They’re almost never there, when they are you’re better off just finding your answers through knowledge bases, and they hardly ever bother to come to the floor even when there’s an issue with a customer. Little to no control over employees which makes it extremely difficult for those who actually work. The lazies can literally get away with just being lazies which not only makes your day harder and seemingly longer but mentally exhausts you. And the best part about it is being told just to deal with it. 


Upper management cares about money more than anything. They push sales but give you a system that literally doesn’t work and instead of taking accountability they put the fault on the sales associates and management. (For example, we were told during a meeting that the system isn’t an issue because stores with higher store volumes are pushing numbers and hitting goals without problem...but the obvious issue is that the system goes down constantly, preventing associates from making sales, so when it does those customers leave without the services they came in for and they will either 1) leave and call customer service and place the order over the phone or at a later time over the phone and save gas 2) give you their number if they recognize you’re the one that sold them, and follow up with you to save your commission. It’s normally not the latter. So stores with lower volumes get hit really hard, when it goes down that might’ve been all the sales that came in for the day. Whereas higher volumes get sales back to back...if the system went down it wouldn’t matter because there’s still 15 people waiting in queue when it came back up.)

Also, since they’re so new in the game with mobile service they’re grossly ill prepared with the consequences that comes with that. And I mean that all around. You have to value your employees and your customers more than the money in your pocket. I’ve worked at cell stores and got robbed before (never at gun point) and they paid to have an officer in the store. You can literally get held hostage with the barrel of a gun on you and this company will do next to nothing. ESPECIALLY if your store isn’t hitting goals. 


Lastly I would say from my experience and where I was it is 100% a family club. Stores feel extremely cliquey, management has friends and family on their floors so they can literally sit on FaceTime and not take customers and get told absolutely nothing. And upper management will just make empty threats because they’re friends with management too. Seriously this job exhausts you mentally. There’s too many changes, no order, no structure, feels like working at the worst kind of startup...but at least in my experience startups care about your complaints and worker’s sanity.
Advice to Management
Just purge newer management and start all over with people actually qualified to lead without complaining about their workload. Also, I’ve never worked at a company that didn’t have a method of submitted anonymous evals which just shows inner retention means absolutely nothing in terms of importance.
